title: ‘It’s made me feel like me’: Boru McCullagh on two years cycling around the world

‘It’s made me feel like me’: Boru McCullagh on two years cycling around the world

In August 2023 Boru McCullagh set off from Herne Hill velodrome in South London for an eight-month ride around the world while fundraising for the mental health charity Mind.

On 12th April 2025 he returned to Herne Hill with over 55,000km, 31 countries and five continents under his pedals and nearly £20,000 raised for Mind.

The journey evolved into a much bigger trip than he imagined, so it’s no surprise that his life has changed a lot since he set off – and not just because of an increased social media following.

‘Life is very different from what it looked like before in new ways that I’m still trying to figure out and understand,’ says McCullagh.

‘It’s so strange to look back on it now because it’s two and a half years of my life but also feels like I’ve just lived this weird fever dream and woken up from a really long nap.

‘The biggest thing that this trip has given me is that sense of feeling that I’m starting to understand who I am and how I respond to things and how I interact with other people, which is very reassuring because I thought I’d never get there. Everyone grows as a person, I just did it in an unconventional way.

‘Spending so much time by yourself and being so reliant on yourself and needing to trust yourself in whatever decision you make and whatever problem you solve and however you do it, it’s just made me feel like me.’

The scenic route

What started as an eight-month plan soon digressed and McCullagh took a much more free-spirited approach to his adventure.

His route went through Europe over the Alps to Turkey, then across India, and through Southeast Asia to Indonesia. He then flew to Australia and crossed the continent, taking on the infamous Nullabor plain, before another epic country crossing of the USA, riding from San Francisco to New York.

The final leg started in Morocco, heading north through Spain and France and then across Ireland before hopping on the ferry to Holyhead in Wales for the last stint back to Herne Hill.

‘The trip definitely evolved into something else,’ he says. ‘I was very naive when I left, thinking I had to do a certain number of kilometres a day, and I had grand ideas about something I thought I knew about, but really I knew nothing about.

‘I started with tunnel vision focussing on what I expected would happen, but I got rid of that and I ended up prolonging the trip by just over a year and a half from what I thought it would be.’

Despite regular digressions from his route, the decision to head back home came in Utah.

‘I was riding in southern Utah in America, one of the most beautiful places in the world, and I just had this morning when I was riding amongst the red mountains and I broke down on the side of the road and had a little cry,’ he says.

‘I felt that I’d seen it all now, and although I didn’t know what I was trying to find through the trip, after that morning I found that. I felt happy that I could go home and feel accomplished and be proud of what I had done.’

A homecoming ride was organised for the final day from Windsor to Herne Hill to welcome his return back to where it all began at the velodrome.

‘My sunglasses stayed firmly in front of my eyes because I was feeling so much,’ he says. ‘I was chatting to everyone around me as if it was completely fine and normal, but part of me just wanted to stop and just have a little moment to myself.

‘It was surreal but also surreally normal at the same time. I’ve been going to Herne Hill Velodrome since I was ten years old multiple times a week and I know the place so well.’

Home and away

Covering over 55,000km takes a long time, and McCullagh has no end of highlights from his trip and the 31 countries he visited.

‘Taiwan has the best tarmac roads as you can just go anywhere,’ he says. ‘For a country that’s so small as the crow flies, it’s so mountainous, and there are high mountains as well so you can get a good range of riding there.

‘I also spent quite a lot of time in Indonesia, the bikepacking and ultracycling community out there is insane.

‘It was also so fun to cycle across India, because there’s no infrastructure for cycling and that’s what makes it so fun. There’s organised chaos happening around you, which is stimulating and engaging because you can’t switch off at all.’

The journey from Wales to Windsor also opened his eyes to the beautiful riding the UK has to offer.

‘Riding through Wales and the UK, I felt this overwhelming sense of oneness that I felt I was part of this painting of the UK countryside and that was like a really special moment for me,’ he says.

‘I’ve never seen the UK countryside in that way; we really do live in a beautiful place. Beforehand I thought it’s just the lanes, you don’t see any uniqueness or appreciate how special it is. My eyes have just never been open to that sort of thing before.’

Stranger things

A residual theme appeared as McCullagh’s travels progressed: talking to strangers.

Having grown up in Eltham, southeast London, the typical Londoner mentality of not engaging with others was a sticking point at first.

‘In London everyone’s doing their own thing, they’ve got their closest people around them but it doesn’t stretch further than that, and that showed itself to me,’ he says. ‘When I first left if I had a problem I’d be on Google straight away rather than asking people.

‘I was uncomfortable with the thought of walking up to someone and asking them about the best roads, and then I realised that local people know their area best, so I should just ask them.

‘People were so friendly, which gave me some confidence and the reassurance that every place isn’t like London, most people in the world do want to chat to you.’

This also played a role in how he managed one of the toughest parts of cycling solo for days on end: loneliness.

‘One of the places I was most concerned that would be the most mentally difficult place was Australia because it is huge and there’s not many people there,’ he says.

‘Beforehand I was trying to hype myself up and be OK being really lonely out there but it’s the opposite. I found it so hard to feel lonely in Australia.

‘I would get to a little roadhouse in the middle of nowhere and just chat to a few people and suddenly feel so much more comfortable.

‘There were little towns that have only survived because there’s a community there and people speak to each other.

‘Of course, there were a few times when I met people where I felt a bit uncomfortable, but for the most part I found that if you’re willing to open yourself up to a place then the place opens itself up to you.’

A new normal

McCullagh has been back in London for over a month but still does not actually know the exact number of kilometres he rode, and while the number is likely closer to 60,000km, he hasn’t dared find out.

‘It’s something that I’m genuinely putting off doing because there are some things that I’m not ready to face yet,’ he says.

‘Once I face it it’s drawing a line in the sand and saying that this trip is behind me now, so working out exactly how many kilometres I’ve cycled or even plugging a charger into a wall and not using my power bank are things I’m putting off until I’m ready.

‘There is something beautiful, simple and pure through seeing the bike just as a means of transportation to get from A to B and I do miss that. It feels weird to not wake up in the morning and say, “Where can my legs carry me?”’

The post-adventure blues are common and, despite his best intentions to prepare himself, adjusting to life back in London has not been straight forward so far.

‘I knew it would be hard because I’d seen other people go through it so I prepared myself for it by having plans and things to look forward to,’ he says.

‘But at the same time, by doing that I don’t feel like I can be fully settled because I have these things to look forward to.

‘I also feel like I’ve lost a big part of myself of waking up and checking Google Maps and being like ‘where should I get to today’ while shovelling down some cold overnight oats that have been freezing in my tent. It has been a big adjustment.’

He already has plans to head back to Asia in October for some gravel races, then to Chile for the Across Andes bikepacking race, and he also some Fastest Known Times attempts on his radar.

However, he’s conscious of making sure he reflects on his mammoth journey before his next steps.

‘You have to be able to stop once in a while and actually digest what’s happened, otherwise you get this huge buildup,’ he says. ‘And, what’s it all for if you don’t reflect on it?’

Thinking of riding around the world?

There are plenty of people who have ridden around the world, from record breakers like Lael Wilcox to adventurers like McCullagh, but everyone does it differently.

‘The first step is saying to yourself that you’re going to do it,’ says McCullagh.

‘Everybody has big dreams but it’s so hard to commit to it before life gets in the way, and as soon as you tell other people you have them to hold you accountable.

‘You don’t need to know everything before you start, there’s almost too much information out there so take whatever you have and you’re going to figure it out. If you don’t have all the right kit to start off with, you’ll learn what you need as you go. One of the most fulfilling parts of is learning about what you’re doing.’

One example of that is that he left armed with five pairs of bib shorts, and over the 2.5-year period he reduced that to two and rarely wore one of those.

‘A pair of bibs lasts about three days, then you just wash it in a sink and it is dry by morning,’ he says.
